column4: what other terminal special characters are there besides ^z and ^c?
ctrl-\, ctrl-q, ctrl-s
and what do they do?
flow control, job-killing
any list of such commands described somewhere?
try "stty -a"
look under "cchars"
sends an interrupt signal to the foreground process
how do i switch between processes?
if you have multiple processes running on a terminal, try "jobs"
so, how do i return to a job?
and how do i make a job run in background?
if you've started a task, you can background it by hitting ctrl-z, and then "bg"
ctrl+z stops the task
if you want that task to run in the background to begin with, just invoke it with an ampersand at the end
and if i just want to start a task, and then, after a while, leave it running and start another one, and then switch back?
ctrl-z, bg, start your other task, background it the same way, then use "jobs" to go between the two
ok, how do i use jobs, there is no man entry, and it just lists the jobs by default
jobs is part of the shell. try "man bash" for an incredible amount of detail
one more thing, how do i make a job stop outputting for a while, while it runs in the background?
if the job is trying to write to the terminal, it will halt automatically when you background it
